awd_titl_txt: Mentoring to Support Designing and Launching of New Data Science Career Pathways at Community Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to strengthen the capacity of faculty in community colleges to design and launch new data science programs. The project includes a partnership between Education Development Center's Oceans of Data Institute, and Bunker Hill, Sinclair, and Normandale Community Colleges. The partnership will support faculty from institutions with existing data science programs to mentor institutions that want to establish their own programs. The mentors will guide the mentees in assessing local industry needs and establishing curricula. The project addresses the need to build the capacity of the nation's skilled data workforce to fill the growing number jobs in data science and data analytics. 

This project will train mentors to share their experiences in developing data programs with faculty from four mentee institutions. The mentors will guide mentees to lead institutional efforts to: 1) Conduct a self-assessment of their college's data program development assets; 2) Develop and implement a strategic plan to create a new data program; 3) Work with employers to prioritize work tasks required to achieve success in local industries; 4) Align courses and curriculum with local industry skill demand; 5) Establish broad, internal support for the new data program; and 6) Develop a new program proposal for their college's curriculum committee. The Oceans of Data Institute will maintain a professional learning community to support mentors and mentees throughout this process, and link them to best practices learned from the Advanced Technological Education MentorLinks and Mentor-Connects projects. Mentors will meet monthly to plan, to discuss challenges, and to share successes. Mentors and mentees will visit each other's institutions to engage college faculty and administrative staff in fact-finding and problem-solving conversations. Mentors and mentees will meet annually in advance of the ATE annual High Impact Technology Exchange Conference to engage in professional development, plan, and problem-solve. The project will deploy resources to support mentee institutions in their pursuit of developing data science programs. These resources will also be made widely available to the public. Outreach and dissemination efforts will target community colleges that would most benefit from this information. The project has the potential to enable community colleges to scale-up efforts and train the next generation of data workers in a sustained and timely manner. This project is funded by NSF's Advanced Technological Education program, which focuses on the education of technicians for the high-technology fields that drive our nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Faculty from Bunker Hill (MA), Sinclair (OH) and Normandale (MN) community colleges mentored faculty from Green River (WA), Harford (MD), Nashville State (TN) community colleges and Bridgerland Technical College (UT) as they developed and/or expanded their programs in Data Analytics. With tools (https://oceansofdata.org/our-workforceprep-work ) developed by EDC in ATE Creating Pathways for Big Data Careers (ATE DUE-1501927) mentees organized their internal teams, conducted an inventory of assets, assessed the local labor market, reviewed the work tasks of the middle skilled Data Practitioner (https://go.edc.org/ProfileofDP), identified gaps between their program/curriculum offerings and local industry needs for data workers, developed/refined their vision for a data pathway and developed their strategic plan to develop/expand their data analytics programs.  To build ongoing collaboration the project established a Community of Practice meeting monthly sharing successes, challenges, and resources.  To date 45 colleges have participated in these gatherings. The CoP continues with ongoing support from EDC.

 

College outcomes: Over the course of this project, collectively, our four mentee institutions developed and implemented two Certificate Programs (Data Analytics Certificate, Data Science Certificate), and three Associates Degree Programs (Associates of Applied Science Degree in Data Analytics and Software Development, Associates of Science in Data Science Program, and Data Analytics Concentration in a Computer Science Applied Associates Degree Program). These programs include more than 36 courses focused on data science education. Each college is now actively preparing students for local middle skilled jobs in data analytics with curriculum closely aligned with local industry skill needs, and interested in sharing their experience with others.

 

In June of 2023 faculty participated in an NSF funded European study tour (Participant Briefing) focusing on how Data Science programs in Belgium and France partner with industry to provide work-based learning (WBL) opportunities for their students. Visiting 8 sites, U.S. educators shard their work, learned of efforts and initiatives abroad, and explored strategies/methods for integrating WBL activities into their college’s career pathway.  The tour provided team members with new perspectives on their work, understanding of what other are doing in similar academic and workforce environments, and strategies to improve their own programs in the U.S.  

 

As a result of this project faculty from participating colleges continue to participate in the CoP sharing their experiences with others, plan additional collaborations and aim to submit additional ATE proposals to continue to expand data science education across the U.S.  In addition, as a direct result of this experience Green River college established a partnership with American University in Dubai through which faculty co-teach a course with students from both colleges working on projects together. As  a final project event, faculty teams participated in the 2023 MinneAnalytics Conference (Bloomington, MN) further broadening their understanding of industry driven WBL in the U.S. and expanding their own networks of U.S. industry data science contacts.

 


Last Modified: 03/08/2024
Modified by: Joyce Malyn-Smith
